assignments.vibrational_mode: G band - in-plane C-C stretching (E2g symmetry)
assignments.rationale: The peak at ~1580 cm⁻¹ is characteristic of the G band in graphitic materials, arising from the in-plane vibration of sp² carbon atoms. The relatively broad FWHM (~32 cm⁻¹) suggests some disorder or defects in the graphitic structure.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari, A.C. & Basko, D.M. (2013). Nature Nanotechnology, 8, 235-246. DOI: 10.1038/nnano.2013.46

assignments.vibrational_mode: G+ band - longitudinal optical (LO) phonon mode
assignments.rationale: Multi-walled or single-walled carbon nanotubes exhibit a G band around 1580 cm⁻¹ from tangential C-C stretching modes. The peak position and width are consistent with CNT samples with some structural heterogeneity.
assignments.literature_reference: Dresselhaus, M.S. et al. (2005). Physics Reports, 409, 47-99. DOI: 10.1016/j.physrep.2004.10.006

assignments.rationale: Large PAH molecules show strong Raman bands around 1580-1600 cm⁻¹ due to aromatic ring quadrant stretching. The exact position depends on the specific PAH structure and degree of conjugation.
assignments.literature_reference: Maltseva, E. et al. (2015). Astrophysical Journal, 814, 23. DOI: 10.1088/0004-637X/814/1/23

summary.analysis_overview: The peak at 1579.94 cm⁻¹ with moderate intensity and FWHM of 32.54 cm⁻¹ is highly characteristic of the G band in graphitic carbon materials. This assignment is strongly supported by extensive literature on carbon Raman spectroscopy.
summary.key_literature_findings: Ferrari and Basko (2013) established that pristine graphene shows a G peak at exactly 1580 cm⁻¹, with peak broadening indicating defects or edge effects. The observed FWHM suggests either few-layer graphene or graphite with some structural disorder.
summary.alternative_considerations: While carbon nanotubes (rank 2) show similar spectral features, they typically exhibit G band splitting into G+ and G- components. PAHs (rank 3) could produce peaks in this region but usually show additional characteristic peaks at other frequencies that would aid identification.

references: Ferrari, A.C. & Basko, D.M. (2013). Raman spectroscopy as a versatile tool for studying the properties of graphene. Nature Nanotechnology, 8, 235-246.
Dresselhaus, M.S., Dresselhaus, G., Saito, R., & Jorio, A. (2005). Raman spectroscopy of carbon nanotubes. Physics Reports, 409, 47-99.
Maltseva, E., Ysard, N., Mulas, G., Joblin, C., & Jäger, C. (2015). Photoluminescence of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in the near-infrared. Astrophysical Journal, 814, 23.

assignments.rationale: The S-H stretching mode typically appears as a weak to medium intensity band in the 2550-2600 cm⁻¹ region. The observed peak at 2670 cm⁻¹ is slightly higher but could indicate S-H stretching in specific molecular environments or hydrogen-bonded thiols
assignments.literature_reference: Socrates, G. (2004). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies, 3rd Edition. Wiley. pp. 120-122

assignments.vibrational_mode: C-D stretching or O-D stretching vibration
assignments.rationale: C-D stretching vibrations typically occur in the 2050-2300 cm⁻¹ range, while O-D stretching can appear around 2400-2700 cm⁻¹. The peak at 2670 cm⁻¹ could correspond to O-D stretching in deuterated alcohols or water
assignments.literature_reference: Lin-Vien, D. et al. (1991). The Handbook of Infrared and Raman Characteristic Frequencies of Organic Molecules. Academic Press. pp. 9-15

assignments.rationale: B-H stretching modes in boron hydrides and boranes typically appear in the 2300-2650 cm⁻¹ region. Terminal B-H bonds can show stretching frequencies around 2500-2640 cm⁻¹
assignments.literature_reference: Nakamoto, K. (2009). Infrared and Raman Spectra of Inorganic and Coordination Compounds, 6th Edition. Wiley. pp. 149-151

summary.analysis_overview: The peak at 2670.19 cm⁻¹ with moderate intensity and FWHM of 49.73 cm⁻¹ most likely corresponds to S-H stretching vibration in thiol compounds, though the frequency is slightly elevated from the typical range. The relatively broad peak width suggests possible hydrogen bonding or environmental effects.
summary.key_literature_findings: Literature consistently places S-H stretching in the 2550-2600 cm⁻¹ range for free thiols, with hydrogen-bonded or complexed thiols showing shifts to higher frequencies. The moderate intensity and peak width are consistent with S-H stretching characteristics.
summary.alternative_considerations: Deuterated compounds (O-D stretching) remain a possibility given the frequency range, particularly if D₂O or deuterated solvents are present. B-H stretching is less likely given the specific frequency and typical intensity patterns of boron hydrides.

references: Socrates, G. (2004). Infrared and Raman Characteristic Group Frequencies: Tables and Charts, 3rd Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Chichester.
Lin-Vien, D., Colthup, N.B., Fateley, W.G., Grasselli, J.G. (1991). The Handbook of Infrared and Raman Characteristic Frequencies of Organic Molecules. Academic Press, San Diego.
Nakamoto, K. (2009). Infrared and Raman Spectra of Inorganic and Coordination Compounds, Part A: Theory and Applications in Inorganic Chemistry, 6th Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Hoboken.
